segments.text: Because then, you know, you should mention Francisco Villa.
Yes.
That man had a lot of people.
That man was very cunning.
Do you know what is cunning?
Yes.
He had a lot of luck.
A lot.
He never fished.
And he, with a gun, where he put a shot, he put the six shots of the gun.
He was very good at shooting.
He didn't sleep with the soldiers there.
He was the only one who knew where he was.
And he took out his ideas and he sent the others who were with him, the generals and everything.
Well, he had many federal soldiers in Torreón.
Yes.
They were raised there.
Well, it's a very big town, that place.
Yes.
And you and your family were there in Torreón during these days or not?
And the Federals were in Piedras Negras, they wanted to throw us out of there.
And your family was in Piedras Negras?
Yes.
And when they found out that Francisco Villa took Torreón, from where we were there was a mountain like 100 miles away, I think.
They ran to the mountain and saw that we were in Piedras Negras.
They asked if they could take us out of here, and they took us out.
And they left it there, and then all the people went back to the same place in Tabonas.
But there, everything...
I lived there for seven years.
And that's what we worked on there.
In agriculture.
And they planted a lot of corn, everything.
They bought all the corn, they sold it in Piedras Negras.
And they named it there...
One ton, which is called in Mexico, is 2,000 pounds.
Well, I sold it for 250.
I sold it for a ton.
And I left a lot of corn for the household expenses, to feed the pigs, to keep them from killing the pigs, and chickens, and cows.
You were living there.
You had other things that you couldn't have there.
You'd go to the black market, you'd take corn and sell it there and buy whatever you wanted.
And you'd go back and forth.
And that's how you were living there.
But when the revolution came and left everything, it was very hard.
It was very hard.
And there was, well, here it's more than the truth.
Sometimes they didn't have anything to grab or eat.
And your family too?
Yes, because if there was nothing to grab, there was no work to do.
We would go to La Pasta to cut firewood and take firewood to sell to Piedras Negras to get what we needed.
And then I thought I would come here.
Me and other boys came here.
And there we were planting onions in Big Wells.
And there I came to Beauty.
There was my wife's father.
There he was.
And there we were.
And there I was sowing in those years there.
And then from there I came here to Grand.
And here I was.
All of these are... Two of them are from Mexico.
He's the eldest in the family, one of the women and one of the men.
That little man was a year and a half old.
Do you know what a year and a half is?
A year and a half, a year and a half.
That's a year and six months.
Yes, yes.
Well, and he, now that he's grown up, tells us here, to us, that sometimes he asks some American men, well, where are you from?
Well, I'm from Mexico.
Well, how are you?
He says, I went through the chest.
Are you wet?
No, I'm not wet.
Wet means he went through the water.
Yes.
And he tells them that he went through the chest.
And they think he went swimming.
He went through the river.
No.
But he makes them say that he went through Chiquilla.
Yes.
Because my wife was in the gas because she was a year and a half, but she was small.
Yes.
That one who is here.
Yes.
He was in the Second World War.
He was in Alaska.
And where does he live now?
Where does he live now?
Where does he live?
He lives in that apartment over there.
Ah, here in Bryan.
His name is Herman.
And there's another son of him who's a junior.
He was in Alaska, and another one was in Houston.
His name was Hermenegildo, but in the army they called him Herman.
What kind of work does Herman have?
Right now?
Yes.
He puts these fences in the yards.
And his other one?
I think about 20 years, I think.
He was working in the dining room of the East, Duncan Hall.
Yes.
And he was the assistant of, who knows, I would say, Treviño.
Yes.
Leonardo Treviño.
That was the one who put him there.
Yes.
And this German was his assistant.
And as he says, it's a lot of responsibility.
And since he was in charge of the working women, and many boys don't want to work, they're very hard-headed, and they fight a lot.
There are times when they fight with each other, and he had to make sure that they didn't do that.
That they did the work well and everything, because at that time, not now, as they say, as the dining room is now.
There is no cleaning like before.
Right now, only women work there.
Only women.
Right now, in this time, people of color don't want to work.
I was working here last year.
Last year was the beginning of the year.
In a yard of trails that are here and there.
Have you seen it?
I think so.
The road that goes here to Casey Hall.
Yes.
I was working with this man here at the store.
He gave me a job there.
And one day he told me, you know, I'm going to bring a boy of color who has worked with me a hundred times.
I said to him, the people of Colorado want to work.
He said, no, he's a very hard worker.
But he took him.
After noon.
He took him.
When the man was there, he was working.
It was only he who came and went to sleep in a room where he was working.
When he came back he made him sleep.
He told me that the boy was working and I told him that he was sleeping there.
He is very hardworking.
He doesn't want to work.
Here is a relative of my wife who works and left the job because of the age.
He worked in the bakery, in the dining room, there in the drawer.
And he said, they put a lady of color there to help me with what was there, and two others to help my brother.
And then he said to one, look at this.
I said, I don't see anything.
Well, then why don't you come here to work?
He said, I don't see anything.
And he didn't work.
And he said, what did he say to the mayor there?
until the mayor told him that if he didn't want to work, he had better quit.
Because this relative of my wife told him, well, you pay a person for not being able to sit down.
You are paying him.
He said, well, he has to work.
Well, he doesn't want to work.
It's a very hard job for me because he doesn't help me with anything.
And they don't want to work.
Both men and women.
Well, why?
And they can't get rid of them?
What is it that they can't get rid of or make them work?
I don't know.
Well, there it is.
That's something that you should see.
And wherever you go, they talk about it.
That they don't want to work with them.
I don't know why.
Like there, as I told the man when I was working there, I told him, hey, it's these men who walk around in trunks.
Are they working with you?
Or who were they working with?
They were sitting all day.
All day.
They weren't working at all.
No?
No.
And they were stopping him.
I told this man, I told him, if you want to find a job, you don't have to work and you have to pay me.
He said, because you have to work, well, and because you don't work.
And that's what I heard today, that they can't exploit them.
I don't know how the law is.
Well, what do you think?
Who works the most?
The people who live in Mexico or the people who live here?
Yes, but as I say, like there in the dining room when I was working there, many girls who didn't want to work, then the...
The man in charge said, well, if you don't want to do the work, go and let someone else come and do the work.
Because the work is needed.
And if you don't want to do it, it's very hard for the people here to get the work from others.
They get the work and they don't pay for it.
Better go and let someone else come and do the work.
And that's how they did it.
Because that man didn't even want to play with the boys.
Because there were many who threw themselves with glasses, because there they had to wash glasses and small and large dishes and cups and everything they had to wash there.
Yes.
I, the time I lived there, I was working in the washing machine.
I was working there.
And that's where I saw many of them, that they were better occupied than because they weren't going to play.
But it's very hard to fight with people like that.
And that's what my girls don't want anymore.
Well, is life different here in Mexico?
Well, it's different, you know why?
As I was reading a newspaper now that says that
Here in this place there was a quake.
Do you know what a quake is?
A quake.
They call it earthquake, I think that's how they call it in English.
Earthquake.
In Nicaragua.
Yes, yes, earthquake.
Well, there I was reading that a Mexican priest says, and another priest, do you know what priest?
Yes.
He's from the Pichas.
Yes.
from Nicaragua, he wrote him a letter, telling him that he was asleep when he heard a noise in Nicaragua.
He said, then I woke up and I looked out the window, through the window, he said, and then I looked at the bed, I saw that the bed moved like this, over there, over here, the bed.
He said, then I went outside and I looked out the street, there was a lot of people in the street.
from all those who had left so that they wouldn't be killed.
Life here is very hard right now.
And there are several problems in that place, because people are very poor.
Very, very poor.
They work and they don't get paid enough so that they can live and dress and have something.
They don't get paid anything.
And that's a very hard thing for people.
And slavery, do you know what slavery is?
Yes.
Slavery is slavery?
Slavery is when, like here, you have to obey what the government says.
Yes.
And you don't get a job.
or they don't pay him and he has to live in misery.
He's a slave.
That's what he tells them to do.
He says, those are several problems.
We have to help the people.
We have to pay them and treat them well.
That happened in Mexico last year.
But not now.
This revolution was what fought for slavery.
But not all governments have done well for the nation.
I'm going to mention López Mateo, who did a lot for Mexico.
And he said he was going to do everything he could so that Mexico would rise up and play just like everyone else.
I don't know how he's going to run, because I don't receive papers from there.
And that's what he needs.
As they say, there are still people in Mexico who don't have a place to live.
Like this bishop Flores, who is Mexican.
It was Patricio Flores, the obispo.
It was in September, the 16th of September, when they inaugurated the independence in Mexico.
So he wrote, he sent a paper saying that still in Mexico, not everyone could scream that it was time for freedom.
He said, because there are many people who don't have a place to live.
so that everyone has the freedom to live.
Well, as I say, the people who live in the town are working in the town, but the people who live outside the town, on the ranch, life is different here.
That's what I think.
But that's why...
I've read books,
because the government of Mexico gave land to all the people to make them live.
But as many people say in Mexico, many people say that they don't want to work.
And many work the land and many don't work it.
But I say for me that the government is to blame for all this.
The government should have people who work in those lands.
But here it's the same, and in Mexico too, I think.
If the government sends, like the president, something is happening here.
He sends a man to come here.
And here the businessmen realize everything.
Well, or they find him, look at him.
And then they say, here, take this amount of money, and you say you're going to fix it.
That's the way you can fix anything.
That's how you fix it.
And that's what happens there, and that's what happens here.
I've read a lot of books, and a lot of newspapers, and that's where I realize all that.
But, well, I don't know what they'll be like.
Because many times,
A lot of people say that you don't know anything.
That you're ignorant and all that.
But if you don't know how to read, you don't know anything.
But if you know how to read, you do know a lot.
Because if you read the newspapers, you realize how everything is happening.
And that's what's going on right now.
Like here, with me, I have a insurance that I'm paying.
One of the collectors who came to...
He came in the car and he stopped outside and he talked to me.
I said, well, what's going on here?
He said, you don't know that I'm coming to see you, that you pay more in insurance.
I said, yes, I pay, but look, I don't support you.
He said, no, just write that you are paying more.
I said, you go, otherwise I lose it.
Why should I be afraid that I'm paying more in insurance?
You go and I go.
I said, don't bully me like that.
And don't bully people either.
That's what I told them.
That a lot of people don't look or know anything.
Because something happened to me since 1925, here in Bryan.
One of my boys, who is in Houston, the youngest of the men, he was about six months old when he was born.
And one of the security collectors from America passed by.
And when the boy was out there on the street,
He stopped with me, I was getting there, I was at work, he stopped with me and said to me, hey, don't you want to put your girls in security?
Look, here they are, a car can come, a horse can come, a cow can hit them and you need to put them in security.
Well, I already had, it seems to me that two, two or three had security.
And I put this one smaller.
And he told me, he said, look,
When he turns 20, they will pay you as if you were dead.
But he lied to me.
When he turned 20, I didn't know anything.
I went to the police station to talk to the manager and I told him.
He said, no, that man cheated on you.
He didn't tell you the truth.
When he was 20 years old, because he was paying five cents a week at that time, and when he was 20 years old, they were going to pay him like he was dead.
And I went to the neighbor and said, no, this man is lying.
Come here, I'll bring you another gift.
That's what you're going to do.
When he turns 20 years old, he can get a bigger insurance.
That's what I should have told you.
I should have told you that I was going to pay you when I was dead.
And that's where I got all that.
And when Mr. Ellis, who ran the insurance at Southern Life, found me in 1945, then I didn't have insurance, nor this, nor my wife.
The boys did have it in the other.
And he told me, hey, do you want to put, do you want to take this insurance?
I told him, I told him, well, it's not bad, I know well that it's good, Alex.
But...
If you're going to tell me the truth, and you're not going to deceive me, because you don't lose anything, I'm the one who's going to lose the money I'm paying.
If right now you say something and then it turns out that it's not like you told me, and you're going to make a fool of yourself.
Two times we met and that's how we were.
Another one came and said, look, here are my...
I said, well, he can say the same thing, but what had happened to me, I didn't want to be trusted anymore.
Well, finally, the third time he came to find me, I thought, I thought, I said, well, I have insurance.
Neither me, nor my wife, nor this one.
And if something happens to me, it's worth more to take it.
And I took it.
And since then I'm paying that insurance.
But I always talked to him.
And I wanted to tell him about that man who came with me here, but I didn't tell him anything.
And another American, not from the same place, came to collect the money here.
I wasn't here at home, my wife was.
And she paid him, but she didn't sign the card.
When my wife came, she told me.
I paid him, he came to collect the insurance, and he took the money, but he didn't sign the card.
And I put on the card what day he had come, how much he had taken.
When another came the next month, I already told him, I said, why do you do that with the people?
You shouldn't do that.
You are the culprits of the evil you do.
We don't, we comply with payments, but you don't carry your books correctly.
He said, well, I don't know why that man did that to you.
I don't know either.
So he left and didn't come back.
Because I don't know where all that will be.
Because right now, all the businesses that I did when I was working, right now I don't owe anything to the house.
I'm paying the taxes,
the security of the house and I pay the bills and everything.
And since I used to take out a hundred times credit in the loans that are here in the town, the way it is that I fall into cards that if I need money, that I go, that I just go and sign.
No.
When I can, when I see that I can pay that money, I go and take it out.
But since right now I'm not working, I'm going to take out the money, how am I going to pay it?
It's going to be bad.
It's going to be bad to take it out.
But as long as they're helping me, I'm doing fine.
That's why.
But I don't owe the house anything.
I wanted to put a chiropractor on it.
My wife had a lot of portraits here.
My daughter took them off because she was going to put a thin chiropractor instead of paper and paint.
Just like I put it there.
I want to put it here.
Nezke just left these there to remove them and put the syrup.
It's not very expensive, it's expensive right now, but... Last year it was...
It was 75 cents, 80, the leaf.
And when I bought that one, I paid 1.18 pesos.
Who knows, now it's worth 1.25.
That's what I think.
Because it's going to be like...
It's been two years since I bought this diary.
That's always why I saw the paper that was very... Let's see, give me the plate.
Here's the plate.
And that's what we're trying to do.
To live well with the people, the neighbors, because otherwise we can't.

But as I was reading in this new paper that I have, the one that fell yesterday, that this bishop Flores says, that he doesn't know why among us people say, we live, that if he has and is living in another way,
One says, how come I don't have that one?
But that shouldn't be like that.
One should think in another way.
Because everything is here.
He gives us and He takes away from us.
Because I am also reading the Holy Scripture.
Do you know what it is?
Yes.
Well, I am reading it.
Every night I read a little.
As there is in the Holy Scripture, there is a...
whose name is Job.
You haven't read the Bible.
And there it says that this man was... well, he was a very good man, and all the time he treated people well, and he feared God in everything.
He wasn't... How can I put it?
that he spoke ill and that he spoke against God.
He never said it.
And it says in the Scripture, saying, being God with his children outside, Satan comes and says to God, where does Satan come from?
He says, I come to turn the earth around, to see everything, to see all the kingdoms it has and everything.
Then God says to him, don't you remember my servant Job?
Who is a fearful man to God, who has never sinned, nor does he curse anyone.
He said no.
He said, well, try it.
Just don't kill him.
Well, God sent him, because he was Satan.
Well, after a few days, he had a lot of
A lot of animals of all kinds.
A lot of them.
And there were a lot of people who were taking care of the animals.
Where?
Where?
These animals?
Like cows, horses, donkeys, camels.
Where?
Where are these animals?
No, they don't say where, they just say that they are here.
Ah, yes.
Well, then...
He was sitting there when a man came in a hurry.
He came and said, I'm here to tell you that another tribe is coming.
They killed all those who were taking care of the camels and took them all away.
That man didn't leave when another man came.
And he said, I'm coming to tell you, I escaped and killed everyone else, I escaped to come and tell you that they took all the horses.
And Taino went to the other one.
And everyone came and told him about all the animals that he had to steal.
And he came, he had three children and two daughters.
When he came, Taino went to the last one, when the other one came and told him, well, you know, I'm coming to tell you that
that your children were having a banquet.
Do you know what a banquet is?
Banquet.
Banquet?
Yes.
Well, he said, and they were eating and drinking.
When a strong wind came from this side and threw the house on top of them.
Then the wife of that man told them, she said, you see,
They took everything.
And why don't you curse your God?
He says to him, woman, you speak like a foolish woman.
Do you know what he means?
He says, you speak like a foolish woman.
God gave me everything I had.
When I was born, I didn't have clothes.
God gave it to me.
God took it from me.
It was all His.
He knows what he's doing.
That's how it happened.
After that, there was a time when Job didn't say anything, nor did he curse God, or anything.
And then, after that, Satan came and took him back.
And from the head to the feet, he put a leper on him.
Do you know what a leper is?
Yes.
Well, he put it all over his body.
You see, he was suffering.
And the woman said to him, why are you hurting him?
What he did was that he put ashes on his head.
And everyone was waiting for the will of God.
God no longer did anything, nor did he say anything.
Then he healed him and gave him more wealth than he had.
And he had seven children.
Five men and three women.
And he said, there were no women in any tribe as beautiful as they were.
But he didn't sin.
That's what I say.
Why do we admire other people and think bad of other people?
We have envy.
Do you know what envy is?
Yes, envy.
Envy.
Envy to envy others.
And they say that we should see what happened with Christ and John the Baptist.
that neither one nor the other spoke a word.
They had nothing to do with each other.
And that's how we should be.
Yes, that's right.
Tell me, please, a little more about your life in Piedras Negras.
During the years 1912 to 1915,
Tell me a little more about your life during these years.
Well, since the 12th we came here to Piedras Negras.
It was called San Carlos, that place.
San Carlos.
San Carlos was the name of that place.
And that place was where the general office was.
And there was another place called Victoria.
We were close to that place, Victoria.
They were, as they say in agriculture, sowing everything.
They were sowing, they named it, who knows if you understand that, the room.

like the one who has his mule shots, all his skulls, harvests, and everything, and he does all his work, and with the owner of the ranch, he gives him a part, and the man who sows takes three parts, this is the fourth.
That's where they were sowing there.
And we picked up the harvest, all the cotton, what we sowed, we sold it like that,
We used to sell the paca in San Carlos.
And that's how we spent our lives there.
When we needed clothes, shoes, supplies, we went to Piedras Negras.
We sold what we had and went to Aguilepas to buy what we needed.
Shoes, clothes, pants, hats.
And so we were going, we were sowing, we were working on the land.
What was hard there, because there were times like these northern rivers that passed in the past, I remembered that you have to water the land to plant in February.
You water the land to plant in March.
And there were times when the north was like this, the northern rivers that came, and you had to walk between the water.
They gave us water up to here.
And it was better to walk in the water than to walk outside because when we went out, it seemed that the cold air was cutting us.
And those seven years were to be watered in February and we had to water in May or June so that the corn was sown, the cotton was sown, and so on.
As I told you, my wife, my children, all the suffering that I went through, now it's all coming back to me.
In what year were you married to your wife?
I got married in 1915.
Three years after you went there.
Three years after...
Yes, because I didn't think of getting married.
That's the truth, as always.
When the revolution was still in Mexico, it was just around the corner.
Nothing stopped.
I wanted to get involved in the revolution.
And a sister of my father told me, I'll take that off your head, you're leaving, we don't know where you're going to stay.
You're not going to know more about us.
And every now and then she would tell me to look for a girl and marry her.
And stop going there.
So many have died there that they don't even know where they're going to stay.
And that's why I got married.
No, because I didn't want to get married.
I still wanted to get into the revolution.
A lot of women got involved.
One of the women who got involved became a colonel.
She was in Mexico City.
That's why I didn't get involved.
I thought it would go well.
I got married in 1915.
It was September 15th.
Suegro, your mother and you?
His wife died.
He was alone.
I was with him.
I wanted to help him.
I wanted to help him.
I wanted my wife to do the work.
But he left.
He came here.
And two years after he came, he wrote to us, asking us to come.
Well, seeing how life was there in Duro, I thought about coming.
I was struggling because when you don't understand the language, it's very hard for you.
For everyone.
It's hard for the people who don't understand anything.
Because they can't see things, they can't ask questions, they don't know the language.
They can't ask questions because they don't know the language.
And it's hard for some people.
When you come here, you can't understand a language.
And that's what I say, that you can't.
Because...
Sometimes they even make a mistake by saying one thing and then another.
And that's not good.
And that's why we came here.
As I told you, we had to stay in that place.
Sowing, yes.
But after the revolution, not when the revolution didn't...
Well, it was all over.
It was all over because the man who lived in that place told everyone that he was being persecuted by the government.
He said,
I'm not going to be able to help them like I used to.
I have to move them to the other side, which was here, to Texas.
He said, when I can, I'll send them everything they need here.
But if I can't, I can't.
Because if I send them, the government takes them away.
It's not good for you or anything.
It's not good for the government.
The problem is that you're going to plant
The land, as they are sowing.
Oh, they will give me whatever you want.
You will have to work.
I wake up and see that there is no help anymore.
They are making us live as they could.
If there was help, they would give it to you, but if not, they wouldn't.
It's like I say, but... And when that revolution... that people said...
The government soldiers were doing a lot of things with the families.
They were killing a lot of people and stealing a lot of people.
Almost all of the people who came from here, they left everything here.
They left all the food.
They lost because they did nothing.
We stayed there, they didn't do anything.
And all that was left, the poor people who were there, who were there before those people came out of here, that was the one who took everything.
And those who left that, they lost it.
They came to this side.
A lot of people come to this side during these days.
Your relatives too?
Your relatives too come here?
They came here?
They came here to Texas, all the people.
All the people, your mom and dad too?
No, my mom died in this place, in San Carlos.
She died in 1914.
And my dad, no, he lived, he died until now, two years ago.
He bought here,
Have you heard of that beautiful valley?
On the side of Matamoros?
Yes, I know that beautiful valley.
Well, near that beautiful valley he bought a land.
A land?
100 acres of land.
Yes.
He bought there.
And there he died.
And two brothers because he got married after my mother died.
Yes.
And that family was in the other woman.
There they are.
This is a portrait of my father and my brother over there.
Why does your family come to Piedras Negras?
For what reason?
Well, you can't see that we went from here to there to sow.
It was my father and me and this man.
We got together, we got married and that's it.
And they were also sowing.
